content.subtitle: One of the questions I see the most asked on StackOverflow, Gitter, and even Google-internal support channels is the difference between the…

paragraphs.text: Dart 2: Legacy of the `void`

paragraphs.name: bbb8
paragraphs.text: A semi-accurate depiction of the universe of void-like types in Dart2

paragraphs.name: 58c2
paragraphs.text: One of the questions I see the most asked on StackOverflow, Gitter, and even Google-internal support channels is the difference between the following built-in types in Dart 2: Object, dynamic, void, and Null.

paragraphs.name: 399e
paragraphs.text: Long-story short, Null (or Bottom in other languages, i.e. “Nothing”) shouldn’t be used in most real user-code, and I suspect we’ll see more articles and lints in the near future to gently discourage usage.

paragraphs.name: 23c6
paragraphs.text: The rest of the three are not as clear, because something in Dart 2 anything can be dynamic, Objector voidat runtime, varying only by the static type signature. So let’s look at a few practical examples of when you should use which type signature.

paragraphs.name: 5af5
paragraphs.text: Object

paragraphs.name: 4bb8
paragraphs.text: Objectis the root class of the Dart class hierarchy, and every other class in Dart is a sub-class of Object — including “primitive” types like int, double, or bool. It guarantees a few things: a hashCodeproperty, an ==operator, a toStringmethod.

paragraphs.name: 1bac
paragraphs.text: Practically speaking, I use Objectlike a poor man’s union type — expecting users to use the isoperator to determine the real type of something before using it. I don’t use dynamic, because, as outlined in the next section, it disables important static analysis and more easily allows you to get into an invalid state.

paragraphs.name: b163
paragraphs.text: Object readProperty(String name) { ... }

paragraphs.name: fb6f
e4f8
paragraphs.text: Another option is to use Object to declare you don’t care what the inner type of a data structure is, for example List<Object> might mean “a list of anything”. This comes in handy when, for example, writing a function that combines the hashCode of every element in a List:

paragraphs.name: 0fd9
paragraphs.text: int hashList(List<Object> elements) { ... }

paragraphs.name: 765a
paragraphs.text: A nice property of Object(compared with dynamic) is that you will get immediate analysis and compiler feedback if you try to call a method on it that doesn’t reliably exist. For example, the following produces a static error:

paragraphs.name: d7d2
92b8
paragraphs.text: In practice though, Object is fairly(and intentionally) limited. My hope is that Dart will get support for method overloads and that will allow me to dramatically decrease my usage of the Object type in real code.

paragraphs.name: 7be5
paragraphs.text: dynamic

paragraphs.name: 6af3
paragraphs.text: I personally never use the dynamic type in Dart 2. From my perspective, it is sort of a union of Objectand a special instruction that tells tools and compilers to disable static analysis checks. That is, the following is legal, and will only present an error at runtime (not statically!):

paragraphs.name: 0a16
5b00
paragraphs.text: In Dart 1, dynamic was everywhere, and any other static type was for IDE and static analysis support — but the compiler (and runtime) treated everything as dynamic. There are still some unfortunate “gotchas” in Dart 2 that can accidentally create a dynamic-typed variable, though:

paragraphs.name: c63e
paragraphs.text: computeAge() => 5; // Return type is dynamic

paragraphs.name: 0fa2
954c
paragraphs.text: Worse yet, dynamic calls lose type information that is vital in Dart 2:

paragraphs.name: 45c7
fca4
102f
9c64
paragraphs.text: The reason for this error is because the actual call here is:

paragraphs.name: b68b
paragraphs.text: users.map((dynamic u) => u.name);
… which does not have enough static type information to produce a Iterable<String>. By fixing users to have the proper type (and avoiding dynamic calls), everything works:

paragraphs.name: 8e6f
paragraphs.text: void

paragraphs.name: dc5a
paragraphs.text: Lastly, we have void, the newest type in Dart 2. In Dart 1 void was only usable as the return type of a function (such as void main()), but in Dart 2 it has been generalized, and is usable elsewhere, for example Future<void>.

paragraphs.name: 8b20
paragraphs.text: A void type is semantically similar to Object(it could be anything), except with additional restrictions — a void type cannot be used for anything (even == or hashCode), and it is invalid to assign something to a void type:
void foo() {}

paragraphs.name: cf7b
7fa8
paragraphs.text: In practice, I use void to mean “anything and I don’t care about the elements” or, more commonly, to mean “omitted”, such as in Future<void> or Stream<void>:

/// Clear the cache.
Future<void> purgeCache() { ... }

paragraphs.name: 07ab
paragraphs.text: In the above code snippet, I don’t want users to try and use the return value of the provided Future, as it is not relevant. I’ve seen examples of using Future<Null>for this purpose, and that was actually a workaround before Future<void>was possible.

paragraphs.name: 6d26
paragraphs.text: For example, this is statically OK, but at runtime is invalid in Dart 2:

paragraphs.name: c931
paragraphs.text: import 'dart:async';

Future<String> _doAThing() async => 'Test';
Future<Null> doAThing() async => _doAThing();

paragraphs.name: 51d6
ac70
paragraphs.text: … where as using Future<void>for doAThing()is valid and correct.

paragraphs.name: 804e
paragraphs.text: Another example might be a Stream that fires without any event data:

paragraphs.name: 233b
paragraphs.text:
/// Fires an event when a user signs-out of the system.
Stream<void> get onLogOut { ... }

paragraphs.name: 2c25
paragraphs.text: Another more practical use is implementing a class with generic type arguments you won’t be using. For example, implementing the popular Visitor pattern, we can ignore the C(context) type argument when it isn’t used by passing void:

paragraphs.name: ee9a
68d8
1b9a
paragraphs.text: I hope this brief article helps you with API decisions around using Object, dynamic, void. Leave comments if you have any other questions or ideas!
